modules.description: This module implements arithmetic operations and comparisons for timespec values, which represent time intervals with second and nanosecond components. It supports addition, subtraction, and scalar adjustments by seconds or nanoseconds, ensuring normalized results. Concrete use cases include measuring time intervals, scheduling delays, and handling timestamps in system-level programming.

This module defines a type `t` representing a POSIX interval timer specification, consisting of `it_interval` and `it_value` fields, both of type `Posix_time.Timespec.t`. It provides operations to create, manipulate, and access these timer specifications. Use cases include setting up recurring or one-shot timers for signals using `setitimer` or similar system calls.

This module represents time values in seconds and microseconds, supporting arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and adjustments by scalar seconds or microseconds. It works with the `t` type, which stores time components as `tv_sec` and `tv_usec`. Use cases include precise time interval calculations, timestamp manipulations, and formatting time values as strings for logging or display.

This module defines a data structure representing a broken-down time value with fields for seconds, minutes, hours, and other date components. It provides operations to construct a valid time record from individual components and compare two time records based on chronological order. Concrete use cases include parsing and validating timestamp data or comparing specific dates and times in a program.

This module provides precise time manipulation capabilities using multiple time representations, including timespec and timeval structures. It supports arithmetic operations, comparisons, and scalar adjustments for handling intervals and timestamps with nanosecond and microsecond precision. Users can create and manage timer specifications for system-level scheduling, perform accurate time calculations, and work with broken-down time values for date and time comparisons. Example uses include measuring execution durations, setting up signal-based timers, and formatting timestamps for logging.
